description.narrative:
Kiambaa Dairy Farmers Cooperative Society and Ndumberi Dairy Farmers Cooperative Society have, over the last year, been discussing possible ways of strengthening their work together with the support of Agriterra and SNV building on past cooperation between the two societies.
After a series of meetings and consultations, the societies agreed to pursue a merger in order to benefit from scale and improved efficiency in their operations.
This is in recognition of the fact that success of cooperatives depends on their ability to address challenges like weak governance, ineffective control systems, limited availability of products and services for their members, lack of innovation and low adoption of technology. An overriding challenge is that many Societies are relatively small, both in terms of membership and volumes, a factor that increases inefficiencies and reduces the value that they can delivery to their members.
Following three consultations held in the first half of 2012, the leaders of both societies met in a workshop in September 2012 to clarify and decide on the kind of cooperation they will continue to pursue. During this workshop, a major milestone was arrived at—a decision that the two societies work on a merger.
A committee comprising representatives of both societies was established and a general framework for realizing the merger agreed upon. One of the outcomes of the merger process is the development of a business plan for a processing milk plant, which is the centerpiece of the merged operation. All other structures and functions in the process will revolve around this enterprise.
The societies clearly stated that their main responsibility is to their members; and securing a market for their produce is at the forefront of all decision making. The current changes in the dairy industry in Kenya and the behavior of key actors especially in the markets has led the two societies to aspire to establish their own milk processing facility—this is the primary motivation for Kiambaa and Ndumberi to pursue a merger—essentially to make such a step viable. This in turn would give the societies greater power in negotiating with that market; maximize on the value of their produce; pay higher producer prices to their members (due to anticipated higher returns per liter of milk marketed); d also support/encourage their members to increase their earnings from increased milk production.
